meanings.definition: To date earlier than something else.
meanings.sent1: I will foredate the meeting to ensure everyone can attend.
meanings.sent2: She likes to foredate her appointments to avoid any scheduling conflicts.
meanings.sent3: The professor decided to foredate the exam, causing some students to panic.
meanings.sent4: His prediction foredated the actual event by several weeks.
meanings.sent5: The historian's research skills allowed him to foredate the discovery of the ancient ruins.

meanings.sent1: The sunrise will foredate the start of our hike.
meanings.sent2: The opening act will foredate the main performance.
meanings.sent3: The cat's meow seemed to foredate the arrival of its owner.
meanings.sent4: The smell of rain in the air seemed to foredate the storm.
meanings.sent5: The first snowflakes foredated the arrival of winter.
